Award.AwardTitle: First-principles studies of time-resolved nonlinear optical spectroscopy signals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Jeffrey A. Cina of the University of Oregon is supported by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop and implement theoretical methods enabling the first-principles calculation and interpretation of two classes of time-resolved spectroscopic signals from condensed molecular systems. In one area, Cina and his coworkers are endeavoring to predict the results of ultrafast phase-coherent multidimensional electronic spectroscopy measurements based on the ab initio determination of resonantly coupled electronic potential energy surfaces. Progress in this direction relies on the framing and implementation of a new theory based on systematically partitioning all intra and intermolecular vibrational degrees of freedom into those that are strongly coupled to the relevant electronic transitions and those that are weakly coupled or not coupled. The other area of theoretical study involves the further development and application of a mixed quantum/semiclassical method for the simulation and interpretation of time-resolved spectroscopic signals from small molecules embedded in low-temperature crystals. An essential feature of these systems, which are under experimental study by V. Ara Apkarian and co-workers at UC-Irvine, is the existence of a small number of relatively high-frequency vibrational degrees of freedom, whose dynamics our theory treats numerically rigorously, coupled to a large number of lower-frequency vibrations amenable to semiclassical approximation.

This work has a broader impact through the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students to frame and solve complex
theoretical and computational problems in collaboration with experimental investigators. Scientific impacts include the development of computational tools applicable to significant problems of widespread interest in molecular science. Both aspects of our theoretical research have the potential to contribute to progress in the areas of natural and artificial photo-synthetic energy harvesting, and molecule-based quantum information processing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research focused on improving the basic, molecular-level understanding of the underlying dynamics that give rise to and are illuminated by experimentally observed spectroscopic signals.  In particular, we addressed the means of operation and information content of time-resolved femtosecond stimulated Raman spectroscopy, in which high-frequency vibrational motions are influenced by and report on slower conformational motion along a photochemical reaction coordinate.  Another study sought to reframe the theory of the popular ultrafast transient-absorption method in order to elucidate certain generic, but imperfectly understood features of TA signals having to do with the way in which intramolecular vibrational quantum beats track collective solvation dynamics.  Finally, we are working to develop efficient quantum mechanical/semi-classical methods for simulating and interpreting small-molecule dynamics and spectroscopy in low-temperature environments. These systems are of special interest because, while quantum mechanical effects are of essential importance at the few-Kelvin temperatures at which these experiments are conducted, it is virtually impossible to carry out first-principles quantal simulations using conventional basis-set methods. Hence, the development and application of semi-classical techniqes, which sacrifice generality for simplicity and computational efficiency, become necessary; the same approaches, if sufficiently well crafted, also promise help in gaining a qualitative appreciation for the relevant molecular dynamics.

The graduate and undergraduate student collaborators on these projects gained valuable, first-hand experience in conducting and sharing the results of scientific research in the area of molecular dynamics and spectroscopy.
